abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is satisfactory,
            sustainability highly likely, and institutional development
            impacts are substantial. Regardless of success, lessons
            address several issues. Although the project was designed to
            maintain the momentum of privatization, yet, the only
            component which could effectively accomplish this, was the
            quick-disbursing component - disbursed during the first year
            of implementation, in a project implemented over an eleven
            year period. At best, Poland did maintain the overall
            direction of the privatization process, though partly due to
            other Bank projects, such as the Enterprise and Financial
            Sector Adjustment Loan Project. Furthermore, institutional
            assessments are an essential part of complex projects with
            multiple implementing agencies; as such, failure to work the
            underlying institutional model in the implementation of the
            program, meant the Bank did not anticipate potential delays.
            Hence, while Poland might not have adopted an alternative
            model for coordination under the project, the Bank should
            have worked the implications of the current model, and
            recommend best practices for effective coordination. Further
            lessons reinforce the need for strong, and participatory
            interagency, and donor coordination, particularly as it
            involves funding, which could have helped the Bank avoid the
            project's over-scaling. And, the value of preparing an
            Implementation Completion Report eleven years after Board
            presentation is questionable, for inevitably, recollections
            are biased; rather, a review of the overall Bank program of
            support to privatization would have been useful.

abstracts.cdata!:
The project's objectives are to
            provide support to Poland's efforts to develop and
            implement an effective enterprise privatization program, and
            implement restructuring across a major share of its
            industry, by: (i) assisting with the design of the necessary
            policies, the establishment and strengthening of the
            institutional framework, and the implementation of the
            privatization program; (ii) providing finance in ways which
            will mobilize additional resources for privatization; and
            (iii) providing finance for enterprise restructuring
            programs. The scope of the project includes: (a) a policy
            component to support the Government's program for
            enterprise transformation and privatization, specifically,
            the implementation of the necessary policy and institutional
            conditions facilitating privatization; (b) a technical
            assistance component principally to support the key agencies
            involved in the privatization and restructuring process; and
            (c) an investment component for privatization/restructuring
            to finance the direct foreign exchange investment costs,
            including physical improvements to production facilities,
            permanent working capital, interest during construction,
            licenses or other types of technology transfer, as well as
            software, technical assistance and training at the
            enterprise level.
